alert.note: Alert for Somerset (New Jersey) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly (New Jersey, Delaware, Southeastern Pennsylvania)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 10 at 10:09AM EST until January 10 at 7:00PM EST by NWS Philadelphia - Mount Holly
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in New Jersey... North Branch Raritan River At Raritan affecting Somerset County. For the Raritan River...including Raritan...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL THIS EVENING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...North Branch Raritan River at Raritan. * WHEN...Until this evening. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Minor flooding begins upstream on Black River Road. At 10.0 feet, Flooding occurs along Old York Road and in North Branch Village. At 13.0 feet, The first evacuations begin in Village of North Branch at Route 28 and Vaanderveer Avenue. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:00 AM EST Wednesday the stage was 12.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 10:00 AM EST Wednesday was 13.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late this afternoon and continue falling to 9.7 feet Saturday morning. - Flood stage is 10.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 12.7 feet on 08/13/1955. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Stream Fld Observed Fcsts (1 pm) Crest Location Stg Stg Day/Time Thu Fri Stg Time Date North Branch Rar Raritan 10.0 12.9 Wed 10 a 5.1 4.2 Crested & Falling &&
info.instruction: Turn around...don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/phi. The next statement will be issued this evening at 700 PM EST.
